commit_message:
Enhanced Platform Awareness OVF Meta-Data Import in Glance

This proposal focuses on how meta-data contained in the OVF package can be
imported automatically by Glance.

Implements blueprint epa-ovf-meta-data-import

Change-Id: Ieeb301dc4521feb079edd7c64a5895b837ae4f2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/04/104904/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================== Enhanced Platform Awareness OVF Meta-Data Import in Glance ========================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/epa-ovf-meta-data-import This proposal focuses on how meta-data contained in the OVF package can be imported automatically by Glance. At the VM deployment phase, Nova, via the Image Properties Filter, can leverage the meta-data imported by Glance to filter the available platforms to a subset of platforms that are most suitable for deploying the VM image on. One use case relates to automatic provisioning of VMs for Network Function Virtualization applications that may require enhanced platform awareness and more fine-grained provisioning of platform resources in order to meet performance criteria. The DMTF CIM models are referenced as examples of meta-data that may be imported. Problem description =================== **Background** There is a growing movement in the telecommunications industry to transform the network. This transformation includes the distinct, but mutually beneficial disciplines of Software Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Functions Virtualization (NFV). One of the challenges of virtualizing appliances in general, and virtualizing network functions in particular, is to deliver near native (i.e. non-virtualized) performance. Many virtual appliances have intense I/O requirements, many also could benefit from access to high performance accelerators for workloads such as cryptography, and others could operate more efficiently with greater access to CPU instruction set extensions. **Network Functions Virtualization** Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) is an Industry Specification Group (ISG) in the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). Leading network operators, TEMs, IT vendors and technology providers have joined the ISG. One of their goals is to "Develop requirements and architecture specifications for the hardware and software infrastructure required to support these virtualized functions, as well as guidelines for developing network functions."[Ref 1] One of the challenges of virtualizing functions in general, and virtualizing network functions in particular is to deliver near native (i.e. non- virtualized) performance. To help address this challenge, developers of virtualized network functions leverage virtualization technologies traditionally associated with IT deployments such as (R)(R) Virtualization Technology (Intel(R) VT) for IA-32, Intel(R) 64 and Intel(R) Architecture (Intel(R) VT-x), Intel(R) Virtualization Technology for Directed I/O (Intel(R) VT-d) and Intel(R) Virtualization Technology for Connectivity (Intel(R) VT-c). They also develop their application with specific drivers for platform features such as Intel(R) Advanced Encryption Standard New Instructions (Intel(R) AES-NI) and the Intel(R) QuickAssist Integrated Accelerator. **Open Virtualization Format** The Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF) Open Virtualization Format (OVF) specification [Ref 2] and the related OVF Envelope XML Schema Document (XSD) [Ref 3] were developed to describe the packaging and distribution of software to be run in a virtual machine. This is one of the open standards that the NFV Industry Specification Group (ISG) in the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) are considering as part of the interface between the higher level orchestration layers and the virtualized infrastructure manager. **DMTF Common Information Model (CIM)** OVF relies on a number of DMTF Common Information Model (CIM) [Ref 4] standards. CIM has defined ~1378 classes/subclasses, with another ~61 Problem Resolution Standard (PRS) classes that can be treated as CIM extensions. With these classes it is possible to model many of the characteristics of the platform that the VM/application has been developed to take advantage of. **Enhanced Platform Awareness** It can be generalized that there is a growing demand for the cloud OS to have a greater awareness of the capabilities of the platforms it controls. The Enhanced Platform Awareness (EPA) related updates proposed to OpenStack aim to facilitate better informed decision making related to VM placement and help drive tangible improvements for cloud tenants. **Sample Use Case** A sample use case for the feature described herein relates to the deployment in an OpenStack managed cloud of a virtualized deep packet inspection application. The application developers coded routines to leverage Intel(R) instruction set extensions such as AVX when they are available on the platform. When packaging the VM, they also configured the OVF meta-data to include in the CIM_ProcessorAllocationSettingData class the InstructionSetExtensionName to have a value of AVX. Leveraging extensions noted in this blueprint, the image would be automatically tagged to request AVX support on the platform. During deployment, Nova would use the image properties from within the image properties filter to help identify the most appropriate platform. **Benefits of OVF Meta-Data Import via Glance Proposal** This EPA proposal focuses on how meta-data contained in the OVF files can be imported automatically by Glance. At the VM deployment phase, Nova, via the Image Properties Filter, can leverage the meta-data imported by Glance to filter the available platforms to a subset of platforms that are most suitable for deploying the VM image on. The use of standardized meta-data descriptions/attributes should help with ensuring related support exists in other parts of OpenStack. The following is a list of some of the benefits of adding OVF Meta-Data Import support to Glance: * Leverage an open, industry standard on the description of permitted key-value pairs applicable to VM virtual hardware requirements. * Standardize the format of platform properties discovered by Nova agents. * Addition of administrator policy controls can restrict properties that can be tagged to an image thereby enabling an admin to control how much granularity they offer tenants in terms of platform requests. * Enable more efficient, higher performing VM deployments based on an enhanced ability to match optimal VM requirements to platform capabilities. * Less error prone workflow between the engineers creating VMs and tagging them with known properties, and the engineers/tenants/administrators deploying the VM in the cloud environment. Proposed change =============== **OVF Meta-Data Fields to Import** The following table describes the suggested OVF meta-data properties that should be among the first to be imported via Glance. This is not intended to be an exhaustive list in terms of keys or values and it is expected that the OpenStack community will extend support as needed. The DMTF CIM documentation should be consulted to get a full list. Open: To help with namespace, it may be better to have the key also contain the related CIM class name and not just the property. E.g. ``ProcessorArchitecture`` would become ``CIM_ProcessorAllocationSettingData.ProcessorArchitecture``. +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ | Name | Key [class. | Value(s) | Standard Info | | | property] | | | +=========+=============+==========================+==========================+ |CPU |ProcessorArc-|Examples noted in the |Described in the CIM_Proc-| |Architect|hitecture |class definition include |essorAllocationSettingData| |ure | |x86, x86-64, ARM, MIPS, |class | | | |etc. | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |CPU |InstructionS-|Examples included in the |Described in the CIM_Proc-| |Instruct-|et |class definition include |essorAllocationSettingData| |ion Set | |x86-i386 instruction set, |class. | | | |x86-64 instruction set, | | | | |ARM A32, ARM A64, MIPS32 | | | | |(32-bit), MIPS64 (64-bit) | | | | |ARM, POWER etc. | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |CPU Inst-|InstructionS-|Instruction set extensions|Described in the CIM_Proc-| |ruction |etExtensionN-|are listed in the CIM |essorAllocationSettingData| |Set Exte-|ame |classes for several archi-|class. Instruction set | |nsions | |tectures such as Intel ex-|extensions are listed in | | | |tensions. Examples of Int-|the CIM classes for | | | |el(R) 64 instruction set |several architectures such| | | |extensions that benefit |as Intel extensions (some | | | |NFV include but are not |of which are listed in the| | | |limited to: |column to the left), | | | |Advanced Encryption Stand-|ARM(R) extensions such as | | | |ard New Instruction |ARM(R) NEON TM, etc. | | | |(Intel(R) AES-NI). | | | | |Carry-less Multiply | | | | |(PCLMULQDQ). | | | | |Advanced Vector Extensions| | | | |(AVX). | | | | |Advanced Vector Extensions| | | | |2 (AVX2). | | | | |Streaming Single Instruct-| | | | |ion Multiple Data (SIMD) | | | | |Extension (SSE) 2/3/4/4.1/| | | | |4.2. | | | | |RDRAND (aka SecureKey). | | | | |Fused Multiply Add (FMA). | | | | |Virtualization Technology | | | | |for IA-32, Intel(R) 64 and| | | | |Intel(R) Architecture | | | | |Intel(R) VT-x).Extended | | | | |Page Tables (EPT). | | | | |Virtualization Technology | | | | |for Directed I/O (Intel(R)| | | | |VT-d) | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |CPU Model|Family |Examples included in the |The Family property in the| | | |class definition include |CIM_Processor class descr-| | | |Intel(R) Xeon(R) processor|ibes processor families. | | | |5400 Series. | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |CPU Last |LastLevelCac-|Examples included in the |The CIM_AssociatedCacheMe-| |Level |heSize |class definition. |mory class can be used to | |Cache | | |specify the cache size. It| |Size | | |is possible to specify the| | | | |size for Level 1, Level 2 | | | | |and Level 3 caches as well| | | | |as other properties such | | | | |as cache associativity and| | | | |cache line size. | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Memory |MemoryType |Examples included in the |The CIM_PhysicalMemory | |Type | |class definition include |class can be used to | | | |DDR2, DDR3, DDR4. |define the memory type. | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Memory |Speed |Units of nanoseconds |The speed of the memory | |Speed | | |bus can be described in | | | | |the CIM_AssociatedProcess-| | | | |orMemory class. Also desc-| | | | |ribed in the CIM_Physical-| | | | |Memory class. | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Memory |ConsumableBl-|Need to reference the Blo-|In the CIM_Memory class | |Size |ocks |ckSize property to determ-|the ConsumableBlocks prop-| | | |ine this value. |erty may be suitable for | | | | |capturing this information| +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Memory |ECCSupported |Examples included in the |Described in the CIM_Comp-| |Error | |class definition include |uterSystemNodeCapabilities| |Correcti-| |{UNKNOWN, SINGLE-BIT ECC, |class. | |on | |MULTI-BIT ECC} | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Trusted |TPM |Examples included in the |A Trusted Platform Module | |Platform | |class definition include |(TPM) is part of the | |Module | |{TXT, , N} |Intell(R) TXT solution. A | | | | |CIM_TPM class has been | | | | |defined in the experiment-| | | | |al part of the CIM | | | | |V2.38.0 schema. | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Platform |PowerStatesS-|Examples included in the |CIM describes power relat-| |Power |upported |class definition include a|ed attributes in classes | |States | |numeric value to map to a |such as the CIM_PowerAllo-| |Capabili-| |power state. |cationSettingData class | |ty | | |and the CIM_PowerManageme-| | | | |ntCapabilities class. | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Hypervis-|VirtualSyste-|Examples included in the |Described in the CIM_Virt-| |or Type |mType |class definition include |ualSystemSettingData class| | | |{KVM, ESXI, HYPERV, XEN, | | | | | N} This field could also| | | | |be used to specify that | | | | |the image should be deplo-| | | | |yed in a bare metal envir-| | | | |onment (e.g. via Ironic) | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Platform |Capabilities |Examples included in the |Defined in the CIM_PCICon-| |PCIe Cap-| |class definition include |troller class. | |abilities| |the identified PCIe capab-| | | | |ilities such as PCIe Gen2 | | | | |or PCIe Gen3. | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |PCIe |VendorID |Passthrough mode results|The CIM_PCIDevice class | |Device |PCIDeviceID |in the entire PCIe device |can be used to describe | |Passthro-| |being decoupled from the |the capabilities of PCI | |ugh | |host OS and fully allocat-|devices. | | | |ed to the guest OS. An ex-| | | | |ample of this technology | | | | |is Intel(R) Virtualization| | | | |Technology for Directed | | | | |I/O (Intel(R) VT-d). | | | | |If SR-IOV is enabled, a | | | | |virtual function rather | | | | |than the entire PCIe devi-| | | | |ce can be allocated to the| | | | |VM. | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ |Local |Technology |Examples included in the |The experimental CIM_Stor-| |Storage | |class definition include |ageTier class can be used | |Media | |Solid State Drive, Fibre |to describe the storage | |Technolo-| |Channel, SATA, SAS, Mixed,|technology. | |gy | |Hard Disk Drive, etc. | | +---------+-------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+ Alternatives ------------ It is possible to tag images with meta-data via the ``--property`` argument on the glance image-create and glance image-update commands. This --property argument takes a key-value pair. The meta-data associated with the image can be used by the Image Properties Filter during the host scheduling process. Potential issues with the existing approach: * If the tenant is to perform the image tagging, then permission must be granted to the tenant to update the image property with the meta-data. * Currently no protection/policy control on what fields they may choose to specify once they are granted permission to update the image. * Some image meta-data key-value pairs have been described in documentation, there is no standard recommended for the myriad of other definitions of key- value pairs that are possible. This makes automatic platform property discovery and correlation with the image meta-data more problematic if a user chooses to add additional meta-data to an image. * The tenant or administrator performing the image tagging are likely not to be the same person or company that developed the VM image and hence may incorrectly tag an image with sub-optimal or inaccurate properties. Data model impact ----------------- The ImageProperty class will be extended to reflect the additional info noted in the table above. Request for input from reviewers on the database migrations considerations that will need to accompany this change. REST API impact --------------- **Part 1: API - Setting to enable/disable import of OVF meta-data** * Add an optional meta-data header to instruct Glance on what to do with OVF meta-data during a POST image command: (``POST http://glance.example.com/v1/images``) * New HTTP header x-image-meta-ovf-meta-import-enable. * Valid values are ``true`` and ``false``. ``true`` means Glance will import all supported OVF meta-data limited only by settings in the policy. * If the header is not specified, the default behavior is for OVF meta-data import to be disabled. **Part 2: Global control of permitted OVF meta-data import settings** * The policy configuration file impacts the implementation of the commands to add and modify images. No API change expected. add_image - Create an image entity ``POST /v1/images`` ``POST /v2/images`` modify_image - Update an image entity ``PUT /v1/images/<IMAGE_ID>`` ``PUT /v2/images/<IMAGE_ID>`` * A JSON list is used to apply policy on the commands above. Policy can define what user role has permission to run the commands. ``{"default": [], "add_image": ["role:admin", role:superuser, "ovf-meta-data-import:XXX", ovf-meta-data-import:YYY", ovf-meta-data-import:ZZZ], "modify_image": ["role:admin", "role:superuser", "ovf-meta-data-import:XXX", ovf-meta-data-import:YYY", ovf-meta-data-import:ZZZ]}`` * The new addition of the ``ovf-meta-data-import:XXX`` item in list indicates that the authorized user may import the meta-data with the key (name) XXX. * If ``x-image-meta-ovf-meta-import-enable`` is not specified or set to false, then Glance shall not import all of the OVF meta-data properties that it supports parsing. **Part 3: Retrieving Image Meta-Data** * It shall be possible to retrieve the image meta-data, e.g. via a HEAD request such as: ``HEAD http://glance.example.com/v1/images/<image-URI>`` * Imported fields shall be available with the HTTP headers: ``x-image-meta-ovf-XXX`` where XXX is the name of the imported meta-data field. **Part 4: Retrieving supported Glance OVF and CIM version.** * It shall be possible to retrieve the version of OVF and CIM models that Glance supports. * Possibly via HTTP headers: ``x-image-meta-ovf-version`` and ``x-image-meta-ovf-cim-schema-version``. Security impact --------------- None directly relating to this proposal. However, there is the possibility of adding OVF certificate verification in a future blueprint. Among other things, the OVF package contains a manifest file with a list of all the files in the package, a hash of each file and the hash algorithm used. To sign an OVF package, the manifest file is signed with a base64 encoded X.509 certificate. The digest of the manifest and the certificate are stored in a .cert file. By validating the certificate and verifying the signature the user can be assured the package has not been tampered with. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ As more features are requested for a VM, there could be an impact on the performance of the Nova scheduling code. Administrators will need to balance the needs to the user (by permitting more/less features to be requested) with the capability of the environment. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- A related change will be needed in the Nova Image Properties filter. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: adrian-hoban Other contributors: alan-kavanagh Work Items ---------- To be added once some initial feedback is received on the design proposal. Dependencies ============ This proposal is related to the following blueprints: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/export-import-image-metadata-ovf https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/metadata-artifact-repository Testing ======= Additional test cases to be added. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation updates will be required to reflect the changes proposed above. Additional Note --------------- Although Intel developed technologies and products have been mentioned in this blueprint as examples of usage, it is intended that the design proposal is applicable to solutions from other vendors. References ========== # Leading operators create ETSI standards group for network functions virtualization. http://www.etsi.org/news-events/news/644-2013-01-isg-nfv-created # Open Virtualization Format (OVF) specification version 2.0.1, document number DSP0243, dated 2013-08-22. http://dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0243_2.0.1.pdf # OVF Envelope XML Schema Document (XSD). http://schemas.dmtf.org/ovf/envelope/2/dsp8023_2.0.1.xsd # DMTF Common Information Model (CIM). http://dmtf.org/standards/cim # CIM V2.38.0 schema. http://dmtf.org/standards/cim/cim_schema_v2380

commit_message:
Federated model for cloning glance objects

A specification for objects cloning capabilities between two glance
services. This spec considers two use-cases: cloning between separate
services, yet within single cloud governance as well as cloning between
separate services, each belonging to separate, federated clouds.

Implements: bp clone-image-across-regions
Implements: bp federated-clouds-image-sharing
Change-Id: I8d7461bffcf91392b1e7037df019fd042cbf4ea8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/97/191897/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Federated clouds image sharing ============================== `bp federated-clouds-image-sharing <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/federated-clouds-image-sharing>` Problem description =================== With the identity federation becoming more and more demanding feature among the stakeholders,it's is time to expand to other OpenStack services and add functionalities getting us towards truly hybrid cloud architectures. Today, in a enviroments where many sites cooperate with a mutual goal in mind, there is a desire for being able to seamlessly share images in between the indepentend cloud deployments. As of today there no standardized workflows for doing so - administrators need to copy images manually. There are solutions, like `glint <https://github.com/hep-gc/glint>`_ however those require maintaining service accounts at each cloud deployment. Proposed change =============== We propose implementing task cloning capabilities where images are being cloned in between independent clouds. This workflow is different from image sharing available today in glance because image file will be really copied (cloned). Moreover, the source and destination endpoint will typically be glance services belonging to exclusive cloud deployments. Identification of the image (being a uuid) will not persist and will be different per cloud deployment. There might be a need for adding object's parameter allowing for global image identification. Proposed workflow looks as follows: #. User authenticates with his local cloud. #. Server responses with a project scoped token. #. User creates a clone task in her local glance where a remote cloud deployment is identified by a Service Provider identificator stored in the local token (this is a part of Keystone2Keystone capabilities #. A keystoneclient (depending on `keystoneauth <https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth>`_) or keystonemiddleware, leveraging on Keystone2Keystone federated authentication will get a valid and properly scoped remote token (target cloud). Keystonemiddleware will also fetch a remote ``image`` endpoint from remote cloud's service catalog. #. A new task is created where following parameters are provided: * URL of the remote image service (glance) * A remote OpenStack token to be used with that service * Identificator of the local image to be cloned #. Glance runs async RPC and starts sending the image to the remote image service (updating its status respectively). Alternatives ------------ * Use tools like `glint <https://github.com/hep-gc/glint>`_ as an non OpenStack extension Data model impact ----------------- Changes which require modifications to the data model often have a wider impact on the system. The community often has strong opinions on how the data model should be evolved, from both a functional and performance perspective. It is therefore important to capture and gain agreement as early as possible on any proposed changes to the data model. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change? * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated? For example if you need to take into account existing images, or modify other existing data, describe how that will work. REST API impact --------------- An /api directory is now included for REST API updates. Each API method which is either added or changed should have the following: * Specification for the method * A description of what the method does suitable for use in user documentation * Method type (POST/PUT/GET/DELETE/PATCH) * Normal http response code(s) * Expected error http response code(s) * A description for each possible error code should be included describing semantic errors which can cause it such as inconsistent parameters supplied to the method, or when an instance is not in an appropriate state for the request to succeed. Errors caused by syntactic problems covered by the JSON schema defintion do not need to be included. * URL for the resource * Parameters which can be passed via the URL * JSON schema definition for the body data if allowed * JSON schema definition for the response data if any * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response * Discuss any policy changes, and discuss what things a deployer needs to think about when defining their policy. Example JSON schema definitions can be found in the Glance tree http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glance/tree/glance/api/v2/tasks.py#n300 Note that the schema should be defined as restrictively as possible. Parameters which are required should be marked as such and only under exceptional circumstances should additional parameters which are not defined in the schema be permitted (i.e. additionalProperties should be False). Reuse of existing predefined parameter types such as regexps for passwords and user defined names is highly encouraged. Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications impact -------------------- Please specify any changes to notifications. This includes introduction of a new notification, changes to an existing notification, or removing a notification. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-glanceclient? What does the user interface there look like? Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system. How often will new code be called? Is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code? Examples of things to consider here include: * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impact on performance. * Calls which result in database queries can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? Other deployer impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that widgets are stored in, how do we handle widget directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the widgets in their cloud? Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the store API, discussion of how stores would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Reviewers --------- Who are the main point of contact for reviewing this piece of functionality? These individuals would have more familiarity with the active development efforts and status of the patch sets. A spec should have at least two reviewers. At least, one of the reviewers should be a core member in the corresponding project. This individual could also serve as a liaison for the developer(s); thus providing them a better communication medium with the other core reviewers, as needed. Core reviewer(s): <launchpad-id or None> <launchpad-id or None> Other reviewer(s): <launchpad-id or None> <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in glance, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Glance: document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g., if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Swift driver with multithreading support

This change proposal introduces a multithreading support in
Swift driver for 'upload', 'download' and 'delete' operations.

This feature allows to accelerate work with Swift backend and
thereby provide better user experience.

Change-Id: I7ac80e3381dc806a58e73325b03ec7d43c934e31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/75/207075/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================== Swift driver with multithreading support ======================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/multithreading_swift This spec propose a new feature in glance_store's Swift driver that enables optional multithreading support. The main goal is to optimize operations on big files, such as uploading, downloading and deleting, and use concurrency with processing each chunk in a different thread. The introduction of this feature is important because it will allow to accelerate work with Swift backend and provide better user experience. Problem description =================== Current driver in glance_store implements its own mechanism to work with big files in Swift. It is synchronous and serial, which means it uploads, downloads and deletes chunks one by one, pending the completion of the previous operation. This solution is not optimal, because it leads to increasing time of operations due to serious overhead. Also all these file operations are already implemented in swift client and they support multithreading as well. It makes another implementation in glance_store redundant. Proposed change =============== It's proposed to use the existing code from Swift client's module Service, that implements high-level operations in Swift [1]. This module has a full set-out of tools and it's suggested to replace current BaseStore logic, like 'add', 'get' and 'delete' with related methods from there, i.e.: 'upload', 'download' and 'delete'. For this two new parameters will be added in [glance_store] section in glance-api.conf: 1. 'swift_enable_multithreading' which if is set True, then Service operations will be used, and the existing in the other case. Default value of the parameter: False. 2. 'swift_thread_number' which defines the number of active threads that will be used for image uploading if multithreading is enabled. Default value: 10. As a possible implementation it is suggested to dynamically override corresponding methods when creating a new object in Store function in glance_store._drivers.swift.store.py This solution doesn't affect SingleTenant and MultiTenant classes, so the whole workflow won't be changed with both single-threaded and multi-threaded implementations. Alternatives ------------ glance_store own multitreading implementation is feasible, but undesirable, because it leads to more code duplication between glance_store and swift client. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The idea of the feature - to accelerate file operations with Swift backend by reducing their overhead. Tests that were made on OpenStack HA mode with 3 controllers and 3 compute nodes showed a dramatically increase in performance: up to 2 times on upload (6-30 minutes for 10Gb file in singlethreaded mode, and 2-40 in multithreaded). Other performance tests results will be added later. Based on that fact we can conclude that overhead is fully leveled and it's possible to upload images at bandwidth speed. Other deployer impact --------------------- When configuring this feature, operators will need to know that it's switched off by default and they have to enable it in config. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mfedosin Other contributors: akhivin Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): hemanth-makkapati ativelkov nikhil-komawar Work Items ---------- - Add new config parameter 'swift_enable_multithreading' and make disabled by default. - Create 'upload', 'download' and 'delete' functions that use Swift client's Service module and add the ability to override the original methods in Store class by them. - Add documentation in Glance repository where it's described how to use the feature. Dependencies ============ The related Swift client's blueprint to create Service module [2] The related commit [3] Testing ======= To test this feature the regular tempest tests is enough. Nevertheless there should be performance tests to make sure that we have desired accelerating. There is the list of performance tests. They should be executed in singlethreaded and multithreaded cases: 1. Upload a regular file, < 5Gb (for example, 2Gb); 2. Upload a big file, > 5Gb (for example, 10Gb); 3. Download a big file; 4. Delete a big file. Documentation Impact ==================== Two new parameters must be described in configuration documentation: 1. 'swift_enable_multithreading' which if is set True, then Service operations will be used, and the existing in the other case. Default value of the parameter: False. 2. 'swift_thread_number' which defines the number of active threads that will be used for image uploading if multithreading is enabled. Default value: 10. References ========== [1] The description of Service module http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-swiftclient/swiftclient.html#module-swiftclient.service [2] The related Swift client's blueprint to create Service module: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack/?searchtext=bin-swift-logic-as-importable-library [3] The related commit: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/85453/

commit_message:
Images list API support specify multi-format or more status

Support to specify multiple format/status values concurrently in images list API.

blueprint images-list-support-multi-status-format

Change-Id: I1404e4519b8fcc61c379d3f15e1bcddf9dfa08de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/35/97535/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= images list API support specify multi status or format ======================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/images-list-support-multi-status-format Allow to specify multiple status/format value concurrently in the images list API. Problem description =================== Currently the images list API allows the user to specify an optional format value to use as a filter - for example to limit the list to only images with a format of ami. However often the user wants to filter the list by a set of image format, for example list images with a format of aki or ari, which requires two separate API calls. Image status filter has the same problem. Allowing the API to accept a list of format/status values would reduce this to a single API call. Proposed change =============== Enable images list API to support to specify multiple format/status values concurrently. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Allow to specify format/status value for many times in a request. For example:: GET /v2/images?disk_format=aki&disk_format=ari GET /v2/images?container_format=aki&container_format=ari Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: boh.ricky Work Items ---------- Implement the support for images list API to specify multiple format/status values concurrently. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Need to document in the API document. References ========== None

commit_message:
Enabled images list API fuzzy query

Currently, images list API only support strictly string match query.
With fuzzy query support, the user can specify string to query all of which query
parameters have the specify string by one API.

blueprint images-list-support-regular-expression

Change-Id: I32d24ab039b27de5e0631b102ccd599a6bec76de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/19/98119/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== images list API support fuzzy query =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/images-list-support-regular- expression Currently, images list API only support strictly string match query. For example, there are three images as system default: cirros-0.3.1-x86_64-uec cirros-0.3.1-x86_64-uec-kernel cirros-0.3.1-x86_64-uec-ramdisk when we use name "cirros", the API return nothing. # glance image-list --name cirros +----+------+-------------+------------------+------+--------+ | ID | Name | Disk Format | Container Format | Size | Status | +----+------+-------------+------------------+------+--------+ +----+------+-------------+------------------+------+--------+ Becase regular expressions have safety problems, this proposal is just to support fuzzy match. Problem description =================== Especially for the user uses the glance to store snapshot or instance backup, the image maybe has the similar string in the image name. For example, a user has images called "bakcup01", bakcup02", "backup03" etc. With fuzzy query support, the user can specify the "bakcup" to query all of them by one API. Proposed change =============== The basic points to note about this change are: * The API return value will change. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The rest API look like this in v1: /v1/images/detail?name=NAME Filters images having a name attribute which has NAME. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Add fuzzy filter by name in the /glance/api/v1/images.py:detail. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <hs.chen@huawei.com> Work Items ---------- * Add fuzzy filter method. * Add test case. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests and tempest tests will check function. Documentation Impact ==================== A description of this function will be added into Glance API V1 Reference. References ========== http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/glanceapi.html

commit_message:
United policy.json in glance

Currently, there is two policy.json files in glance.
One for glance code(glance/etc/policy.json), one for
glance unit test code(glance/tests/etc/policy.json).
It's not convenient for the developer and easy to
miss one.This blueprint is aim to united them. Then
unit test code will use the policy.json in the
code(glance/etc/policy.json).

blueprint united-policy-in-glance

Change-Id: Id6effff7bb3b2ff4a2392549b8a3046007cabe12
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/74/105474/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ United Policy.json In Glance ============================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/united-policy-in-glance Currently, there is two policy.json files in glance. One for glance code, one for unit test code. It's not convenient for the developer and easy to miss one. This blueprint is aim to united them. Then unit test code will use the policy.json in the code. Problem description =================== Currently, there is two policy.json files in glance. One for glance code, one for unit test code. It's not convenient for the developer and easy to miss one. Proposed change =============== *Delete the policy.json under the test *Modify the unittest to use the file glance/etc/policy.json Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: boh.ricky <boh.ricky@gmail.com> Work Items ---------- *Delete policy.json in the test *Modify the unittest to use glance/etc/policy.json Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Add log translation hints for glance

Current oslo libraries support translating log messages using different
translation domains and oslo would like to see hints in all of our code
by the end of juno. So glance should handle the changes out over the
release.Relate info about log translation hints as follows:
    https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/log-messages-translation-domain-rollout
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70455

blueprint support-log-translation-hints

Change-Id: I602bb5a5c04464dd715080621a503602119395f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/70/105670/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Add log translation hints for glance ==================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/support-log-translation-hints To update glance log messages to take advantage of oslo's new feature of supporting translating log messages using different translation domains. Problem description =================== Current oslo libraries support translating log messages using different translation domains and oslo would like to see hints in all of our code by the end of juno. So glance should handle the changes out over the release. Proposed change =============== Since there are too many files need to change, so divide this bp into 13 patches according to glance directories. glance  api  cmd  common  db  domain  hacking  image_cache  openstack  quota  registry  store  tests For each directory's files, we change all the log messages as follows. 1. Change "LOG.exception(_(" to "LOG.exception(_LE". 2. Change "LOG.warn(_(" to "LOG.warn(_LW(". 3. Change "LOG.info(_(" to "LOG.info(_LI(". 4. Change "LOG.critical(_(" to "LOG.info(_LC(". Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Work Items ---------- For each directory's files, we change all the log messages as follows. 1. Change "LOG.exception(_(" to "LOG.exception(_LE". 2. Change "LOG.warn(_(" to "LOG.warn(_LW(". 3. Change "LOG.info(_(" to "LOG.info(_LI(". 4. Change "LOG.critical(_(" to "LOG.info(_LC(". We handle these changes in the following order: glance glance/api glance/cmd glance/common glance/db glance/domain glance/hacking glance/image_cache glance/openstack glance/quota glance/registry glance/store glance/tests Add a HACKING check rule to ensure that log messages to relative domain. Using regular expression to check whether log messages with relative _L* function. log_translation_domain_error = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.error\(\s*_LE\(('|\")") log_translation_domain_info = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.info\(\s*_LI\(('|\")") log_translation_domain_warn = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(warn|warning)\(\s*_LW\(('|\")") log_translation_domain_critical = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.critical\(\s*_LC\(('|\")") Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1]https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/log-messages-translation-domain-rollout [2]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70455 [3]https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards

Use target descriprion in policy

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Improved Policy - using target ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/use-target-in-policy Currently Glance doesn't support target description in the policy file. It would be good to have such possibility like the other main services. Problem description =================== When creating the image it is impossible to specify any parameters of that in the policy file. For example, there is no way to deny users create the image, but allow to make snapshots. It is impossible to restrict uploading images basef on their size etc. Proposed change =============== Improvement of Glance policy engine. Allows to analyze the metadata properties of the image. In its turn this allows to specify image properties in the policy file, for example: to allow Only images with property snapshot (Nova specifies it when creating the snapshot). In policy.json should be specified the next: "add_image": "'snapshot':%(target.image.image_type)s" Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <agrebennikov> Work Items ---------- Improve the policy engine of Glance (1 item). Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test will check new functionality. Documentation Impact ==================== New feature needs to be mentioned. References ========== None

commit_message:
Add community-level image sharing

blueprint community-level-v2-image-sharing

Change-Id: Ic54a8a674f527fbf9a055d242564ca039242b7dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/50/124050/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================= Add community-level image sharing ================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/community-level-v2-image-sharing Add a new feature which allows a user to share an image with all other tenants. These "community" images do no appear in image listings for a user until that user has accepted the image. This new feature is a simple extension of the current image sharing functionality. The sharing is achieved using existing image membership mechanisms, and remains consistent with the associated rules. Problem description =================== Currently, there is no provision for an image to be available for use by users other than the owner of the image, unless the image is either made public or explicitly shared by the owner of the image with other users. If the number of users who require access to the image is large, the overhead of explicit sharing can become a burden on the owner of the image. Public images appear in ``image-list`` for all users, which can be undesirable, as shown in the following section. Use cases --------- 1. An open source project wants to make a prepared VM image available so users simply boot an instance from that image to use the project's software. The developers of the project are too busy writing software to worry about the hassle of maintaining a list of "customers" as they'd have to do with current v2 image sharing. At the same time, the cloud provider hosting the prepared image doesn't want to make this image public, as that would imply a support relation that doesn't exist between image consumers and the cloud provider. 2. A cloud provider wants to discourage users from using a public image that is getting old, for example an image which is missing some security patches or is no longer supported by the vendor, but doesn't want to delete the image because some users may still require it. Users could need the old image to rebuild a server, or because they have custom patches for that, particular image. In either case, the vendor could make the image a "community' image and alleviate the challenges presented above. This means that: a) The community image won't appear in user's default image lists. This means they won't know about it unless they are motivated to seek it out, for example by asking other users for the UUID. b) Since the image is no longer "public," it doesn't imply the same level of support from the vendor as a provider-supplied public image. Proposed change =============== The chosen method of implementing this functionality is to add a membership record for an image that has a target of ``"*"`` (i.e. it is shared with all tenants) but with ``membership_status = "community"``. This marks it as a community image very simply and requires few modifications to existing code. This respects the current anti-spam provisions in the glance v2 api; when an image owner makes an image a "community" image, any other tenant should be able to boot an instance from that image, but the image will not show up in any tenant's default image-list. Alternatives ------------ Adding image aliases ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A completely different way of solving the usecase for cloud providers (discouraging users from using an older version of a public image) could be to create a mechanism to make an image alias, which could point at the newest version of the public image. There is a abandoned blueprint for this feature [#]_. This, however, is much harder to implement and does not fit with the other usecases. .. [#] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/glance-image-aliases Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Image discovery ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Community images will be displayed in an image listing only if the ``visibility`` filter is set to the value ``'community'``. :: GET /v2/images?visibility=community All other appropriate filters will be respected. Of note is the use of an ``owner`` parameter. This, when supplied together with the ``community`` filter, allows a user to request only those community images owned by that particular tenant: :: GET /v2/images?visibility=community&owner={tenantId} Accepting a community Image ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Having to filter the results each time to find a particular image is inconvenient, particularity if that image is often used. To remove this inconvenience, users are allowed to "bookmark" a particular community image. This image then appears in the user's image-list. This functionality operates in much the same way that v2 image sharing works, but the owner of the image does not have to maintain relationships with each of the new image consumers. If a consumer of a community image would like to bookmark it, they must: 1. Add their tenant ID as a member of the community image. 2. Accept the image so it will appear in their image-list For this, the existing image-sharing API calls will be used: 1. Add the tenant ID to the image: :: POST /v2/images/{image_id}/members Request body: :: {"member": "8989447062e04a818baf9e073fd04fa7"} The response and other behaviour remains the same as was previously defined for this call. 2. Accept the image: :: PUT /v2/images/{image_id}/members/{member_id} Request body: :: {"status": "accepted"} Again, the response and other behaviour remains the same as was previously defined for this call. Making an image a "community image" ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The owner of an image can use the existing image-update call, changing the image's visibility to ``'community'``: :: PATCH /v2/images/{image_id} Request body: .. code:: json [{ "op": "replace", "path": "/visibility", "value": "community" }] The response and other behaviour remains the same as was previously defined for this call. Removing a community image ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A community image can be removed from community-level access by also using the image-update call. Instead of setting it to ``'community'`` as before, we set it to ``'private'``: :: PATCH /v2/images/{image_id} Request body: .. code:: json [{ "op": "replace", "path": "/visibility", "value": "private" }] As in all the above cases, the response and other behaviour remains the same as was previously defined for this call. Security impact --------------- Little to none. The only risk is for users to accidentally leak potentially sensitive images by accidentally making them community images. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Client changes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Python-glanceclient will be updated to expose this feature. An option to ``glance image-update`` will be added named ``--visibility <VISIBILITY_STATUS>``, where ``VISIBILITY_STATUS`` may be one of ``{public, private, community}``. For example, to make an image a community image: .. code:: bash $ glance image-update --visibility community <IMAGE> To make the image private again: .. code:: bash $ glance image-update --visibility private <IMAGE> Membership behaviour ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Moving from community to public retains the list of members the image currently contains. This maintains constancy with the current membership behaviour. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kragniz Other contributors: iccha-sethi Work Items ---------- - Add functionality for storing the community state in the interfaces to both db backends: + sqlalchemy + simple - Add functionality to enable this and accepting the image in the api - Add unit tests to test various inputs to the api - Add functional tests for the lifecycle of community images - Update glanceclient with the new option Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= A tempest test must be added to cover creating a community image and it transitioning between public and private states. Documentation Impact ==================== New features must be documented in both glance and python-glanceclient. References ========== None

commit_message:
Support OVF Artifact

OVF (Open Virtualization Format) is widely used for virtual appliance. A OVF
package can be a set of files, or can be stored as a single
file, OVA file, using the TAR format.

Store the OVF files in glance is the first step for OVF support in openstack
and the artifact mechanism will be used for it.

Change-Id: I3bd5fa47de866e40fb96f012ecb8f7d489037e00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/05/138905/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support OVF Artifact ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/ova-upload OVF (Open Virtualization Format) is widely used for virtual appliance. A OVF package can be a package with multiple files, or can be stored as a single file, OVA file, using the TAR format. It will be good to support launching virtual appliance from OVF. The first step to support OVF is to store it in the openstack and glance is the right choice utilizing the artifacts support, see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/metadata-artifact-repository for more information of the artifacts. Problem description =================== OVF file is used for virtual appliance. Launching a virtual appliance in openstack requires firstly storing the OVA file in the openstack. Application catelog like Murano, can then utilize this storage to launch the corresponding openstack instances. The OVF spec is located at http://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0243_1.1.0.pdf and http://dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0243_2.0.0.pdf. Proposed change =============== A new artifact type OVF is supported and the corresponding plugin is added. Please check https://review.openstack.org/#/c/100968/8/specs/juno/artifact-repository.rst for the artifact type plugin requirement. The OVF plugin will support to upload a OVF package, either as a single file, or as a set of file (refer to section 5.3/5.4 in OVF spec) to glance and store them. In our first step, we will only support comformance level 2 OVF packages. The OVF artifact plugin will ignore most of the virtual system and virtual system collection information, since launch the appliance is out scope of this spec. Instead, the OVF plugin will focus on the reference section and product information. **Blob kind** The files for the OVF packages will be stored as artifact blob. The blob kind definitions are: Name: Descriptor Count: 1 Requried: True Name: manifest Count: 0 Requried: False Name: Certificate Count: 0 Requried: False Name: Image Count: 0 Requried: False Name: Icon Count: 0 Requried: False All files that are referenced in DiskSection will be intepreted as Image. **Image files** Some special notice needed for the image blob. Firstly, we have some limitatin in the initial implementation. -we only support relative-path reference as file reference -we don't support the relative directories -We will not support the chunk either. -We don't support disk element with parent image. The image blob will be uploaded through the artifacts blob interface, and kept as image. Some special image tags are added to the images, including: artifact_id, ovf:diskId, ovf:fileRef, The OVF artifact will keep refererence to the image through keeping the mapping from the ovf:diskId to the image id. For disk w/o file refence (i.e. the empty disk), an empty image will be created. The dependency of the artifact and image file is not supported now in the artifact BP, will be discussed in future. **ProductSection** The OVF artifact plugin parses the product section in the OVF file and keep followed element as artifact property: Product/Vendor/Version/FullVersion/ProductUrl/VendorUrl/Icon. **Publishing check** Below is the critierial to passing the publishing check: a) One and only one descriptor file (.ovf file) existed b) SHA digests is correct. c) Signature is correct d) All FileReference has been uploaded. e) DiskSectioin is valid. f) ProductionSection is valid We may add more sanity checking in future like. The publishing check will not validate all sectios in .OVF file is valid. **OVA file upload** A task type will be created to upload OVA file. The task will decompress the OVA file and then invoke the corresponding OVF artifact plugin mechanism. After the task is successful, the OVF package will be in ACTIVE state. Alternatives ------------ There are several alternatives. There are some effort to boot a nova instance from a OVA file directly https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-driver-ova-support which is achieved in nova VMWare driver and is not generic one and has multiple limitation like multiple disk support, virtual system collections support etc. Data model impact ----------------- We will reuse the data model provided by the artifacts. The artifact specific metadata will be stored at artifacts properties table. REST API impact --------------- We will reuse the artifact API definition, with the artifact_type as OVF. Security impact --------------- N/A Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- A new task type added. A new artifact type added. Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Other deployer impact --------------------- N/A Developer impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- yunhong-jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com> <launchpad-id or None> Reviewers --------- N/A Work Items ---------- Artifact plugin OVA upload task Dependencies ============ * Depends on artifacts ( https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/metadata-artifact-repository) support. Testing ======= We will try to upload a OVA file and verify the information through glance, and then download it to verify it's correct. We will also test invalid OVF package. Documentation Impact ==================== This effort will add support for OVF package storage, thus will need document update. References ========== http://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0243_1.1.0.pdf http://dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0243_2.0.0.pdf

subject: Spec for glance multi-store support
