commit_message:
Spec for glance multi-store support

Although the current glance implementation supports multiple locations
per image, it currently does not support a means to configure and use
multiple instances of the same store type / scheme. As a result
out-of-band-operations may be required to back image bits on secondary
storage.

This spec contains a proposal to support multiple stores of the same
type (scheme) within the glance service which includes a new
glance REST API for stores in addition to store targeting integration
with image upload and download.

The multi-store support outlined in this spec paves the road for a
number of use cases related to image fault tolerance, image
locality and policy based image hosting.

Base on blueprint multi-store

Change-Id: Id552639fcaa5e4412ee5f8318d7520caa7f332d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/67/150967/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Glance multi-store support ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/multi-store Glance currently supports a single store per scheme (file, vsphere, etc.) and as a result image bits can only be backed (in-band) in a single backend on a per scheme basis. While this approach suffices for a number of use cases, ideally glance would support multiple stores of the same scheme and expose capabilities to discover and target those backends for (applicable) v2 image operations. Multi-store support opens the door to a handful of image replication and backend targeting use cases which can provide additional value related to fault tolerance, image locality and policy based image hosting. Consider the following use cases which can be solved using multi-store support in glance: * As an operator, I want to configure multiple stores of the same type / scheme so I can target them (upload / download) for image locality characteristics. * As an operator, I want to configure multiple stores of the same type / scheme so that I can replicate / serve image bits across multiple backends for fault tolerance guarantees. * As an operator, I want to configure multiple stores of the same type / scheme so I can target them (upload / download) for image storage policies. * As an operator, I want to query glance to discover all store backends currently configured for the service. * As an operator, I want to get details about a specific store. * As an operator, I want greater visibility into the backend store(s) currently backing my image(s). This spec proposes an approach to providing the glance multi-store support. Problem description =================== At the moment glance only supports a single store per scheme. So for example, if an operator wanted to configure the vmware datastore store driver for 2 backend vCenter servers (1 per store), this is not possible today without substantial changes to the store driver code itself. Even if the store driver code was changed, the operator today would still have no means to upload / download image bits from a targeted store without using direct image URLs. As a result, operators today must perform a number of manual steps in order to replicate or target image bits on backend glance stores. For example, in order to replicate a existing image's bits to secondary storage of the same type / scheme as the primary: * It's a manual out-of-band task to copy image bits to secondary storage. * The operator must manage store locations manually; there is no way to query the available stores to back an image's bits in glance. * The operator must remember to register secondary location URL using the glance API. * Constructing the location URL by hand is error prone as some URLs are lengthy and complex. Moreover they require knowledge of the backing store in order to construct properly. Also consider the case when a glance API consumer wants to download the image bits from a secondary backend location which was added out-of-band. Today the consumer must use the direct location URL which implies the consumer needs the logic necessary to translate that direct URL into a connection to the backend. The above pain points can be alleviated in the multi-store support proposed herein. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes the following high level features to support multiple stores of the same scheme / type: * Support in the glance-api.conf and supporting logic to configure, manage and use multiple stores of the same type / scheme. * A new REST API to list all configured stores known to the glance service. * A new REST API to get the details about a particular store by it's store_id. * Enhance the image upload API to (optionally) support targeting a backend store for the image bits. * Enhance the image download API to (optionally) support targeting a backend store to download the image bits from. * Additional metadata attribute(s) added to an image locations' metadata properties related to backing stores. Let's discuss each of these in turn. **Conf / Core multi-store support** To support multiple stores of the same scheme / type, glance must implement the core logic to configure, instantiate, manage and interface with multiple stores, perhaps of the same type / scheme. Cinder addressed the same issue with multi-backend support [1]. However from a runtime / topology perspective, cinder decided to run each volume driver as its own service and put a scheduler in front of them to schedule requests. What's proposed here is to take a similar approach to cinder multi-backend from a configuration perspective, but instead of running each store driver as a stand-alone service continue to use the backend scheme_map [2] as is done today in glance. That is; glance store drivers are accessed at the object level, not the service level. From a conf file perspective, a single property in the 'glance_store' property group should be used to drive the multi-store configuration support. Consider the following example snippet of glance-api.conf which configures 3 stores for use:: [glance-store] # list of enabled stores identified by their property group name # if not set multi-store is not used (backwards compat) enabled_stores = localfs,vsphere-east1,vsphere-west1 # the default store, if not set the 1st store is the default default_store = vsphere-east1 # etc.. # conf props for file system store instance [localfs] store_type = file filesystem_store_datadir = /var/lib/images/data/ # etc.. # conf props for vmware datastore store instance [vsphere-east1] store_type = vmware vmware_server_host = 9.10.78.11 # etc.. # conf props for vmware datastore store instance [vsphere-west1] store_type = vmware vmware_server_host = 10.10.90.32 # etc.. As show in the example above the 'enabled_stores' property is a comma delimited list of store identifiers which are setup for glance. Each of the store identifiers defines a property group name which itself contains the store specific properties used to configure the store instance. One non-store specific property must be defined per store property group called 'store_type' which identifies the type of store the conf group properties are for. Under the covers the store identifier (aka id) maps to the store class used for the instance. The list of glance store drivers and their types are defined using standard stevedore extensions in the setup.cfg (as done today). For example:: [entry_points] glance_store.drivers = file = glance_store._drivers.filesystem:Store vmware = glance_store._drivers.vmware_datastore:Store # etc.. For backwards compatibility, an operator can leave the 'enabled_stores' property unset in which case multi-store support is not "enabled" and glance the semantics we have today work as-is. Moreover the 'default_store' conf property can refer to a store identifier when running in multi-store mode to signify which store instance is the default and should be used for applicable operations when a user does not explicitly target a specific store via store identifier. Note: if glance is not running in multi-store mode, each store configured (e.g. at most 1 store per scheme) is given the default identifier of the store type (e.g. file, vmware, etc.). This behavior allows stores to have a unique store ID even when not using multi-store. Note that from within a glance store driver, the semantics of running in "multi-store mode" are hidden; the driver continues to function as-is today unaware of other store instances with the same scheme. In order to accommodate multiple stores of the same scheme, the scheme_map [2] used to index stores must also index by store identifier per scheme. The store identifier is (implicitly) the name of the conf group given in the glance-api.conf (e.g. fs1, vsphere-east1 and vsphere-west1 from the example conf given above) or it will be the store type (e.g. 'file', 'vmware') if not using multi-store support. Consider the following indexing approach:: scheme_map[scheme][store_id] Where 'scheme' is the scheme(s) supported by the store implementation and 'store_id' is the identifier for the store. Additional "core" changes are likely required to handle a multi-store based scheme. For example, the image delete codepath will need to ensure the proper store is looked up when deleting all image locations [3]. **API to list stores** To accommodate the management and discovery of known glance stores, glance should also provide a REST API which permits authorized users to list all stores configured for glance. This is a read-only list of glance stores which includes the schemes supported by each store as well as the store's identifier, base locations and type. NB: the list of glance stores is based on the glance-api.conf with respect to store configuration. Operators will not be able to configure new stores using the API. As discussed herein, the store identifier can be used to address a particular instance of a store for applicable operations such as image upload and image download. We also propose the store driver interface be updated to include a new method which concrete store implementations must implement. This new method should return a list of unique base locations which are served by the respective store instance. For example consider the following:: def get_base_locations(self): """ Returns a list of unique base locations served by this store instance. The base locations are typically the image location base URLs produced by images stored in this instance. e.g. vsphere://my_host:port/datacenter/ or file:///var/glance/images/ """ These base locations are returned when listing store instances and can be used in subsequent features which leverage multi-store support. We propose the new REST resource be located at the following URI:: /{api_version}/stores Where 'api_version' is the glance API version being invoked. For example:: /v2/stores More details on this API can be found in the REST API section of this spec. **API to get store details** Given we've introduced the new REST resource called 'stores' (e.g. /v2/stores) it makes sense to include an API for consumers to get details about a particular store. For example; "I have the store ID and I want to obtain the details about this store". We propose the following API be added:: /{api_version}/stores/{store_id} Where 'api_version' is the version of the glance API and 'store_id' is the unique store identifier as described in core multi-store changes section. This call should be trivial to implement considering we should have an in-memory mapping of stores. Although one could see a number of addition useful APIs are part of the 'stores' resource (e.g. a PUT to dynamically create a new store or DELETE to remove and existing store), this spec only proposes to add support the GET verb which will retrieve the details about a given store. More details on this API can be found in the REST API section of this spec. **Image upload API** The existing image upload API permits an operator to upload image bits to the glance service. However today this API does not provide a means for the operator to target a specific store to back the image bits on (technically the v1 API allows you to specify a store scheme to target). This spec proposes the API be enhanced to permit an operator to specify which store will back the image bits being uploaded. We propose a header field be used as a means to transport the identifier of the store to back the image bits. Again the identifier under the covers is the property group name of the respective glance store driver. When the image upload API is used to upload image bits, the glance logic will determine if the target store header is specified, and if so the image bits will be added to the target store. If no store is targeted in the upload request, the 'default_store' is used to back the image bits. Using this scheme operators will be able to specify which store they want an image bits to be backed on during an upload operation. In accordance with the glance v1 APIs, we propose the 'X-Image-Meta-Store' header be used as the means to transport a target store identifier. More details on this API can be found in the REST API section of this spec. **Image download API** The existing image download API permits and operator to download image bits from the glance service. However, today users cannot specify which backend location they wish to download the image bits from; those details are not exposed at the API level unless the user leverages the image's location URL directly. This spec proposes a means for users to (optionally) specify which backend store to download the bits from. This spec proposes a header field be used as a means to transport the identifier of the store to download the image bits from (where the identifier is the store identifier is implicitly defined by the stores property group name in the glance-api.conf). When the image download API is used to download image bits, the glance logic will determine if the header is specified, and if so use the get() method of the specified store to stream the image bits from the targeted store. If no store is specified in the download request, the default_store is used to stream the image bits from. Using this scheme operators will be able to specify which store they want an image bits to be streamed from during an download operation. In accordance with the glance v1 APIs, we propose the 'X-Image-Meta-Store' header be used as the means to transport a target store identifier. More details on this API can be found in the REST API section of this spec. **Store locations metadata attributes** In the current glance API, a consumer of the glance API has no way to correlate an image location with its respective store other than by inspecting the image's location URL. While this may work fine for many use cases, a more user friendly relation is needed in a multi-store environment; user's need an explicit relation between an image location and it's respective store (e.g. what store is this location backed on). This spec proposes that when image bits are add with the image upload API, the core glance logic is responsible for adding a metadata attribute to the image location URL to reflect the backing store's identifier. For example, if a user uploads an image to the 'vsphere-west1' store in our example above, once the image bits are uploaded, the image location URL is added and in the URL's metadata a property with the store's identifier is added to the location metadata object. With the store identifier in the image location URL metadata, API users can simply inspect the image location's URLs and get the store identifier per image location. The store identifier can then be used for subsequent operations or within the API consumers logic. Alternatives ------------ Two major alternatives come to mind with respect to a multi-store approach in glance; multi-store using a service per store and per driver multi-store support. **Per store service** In the service per store approach, each of the configured store instances would run as a separate process / service. As a result each service would have it's own AMQP / RPC interface, own PID, etc.. To route requests to store services, we'd use a scheduler which itself is another process / service. This is the same approach used in cinder multi-backend support [1]. Although the service per store approach may be a longer term goal for glance, today we haven't seen enough justification from our consumer base to justify the major refactoring / changes which are required to move glance to this model. Therefore this spec proposes the multi-store approach outlined within this spec - let's get an initial approximation multi-store working and gage our next steps based on consumer feedback in the community. **Per driver support** Another potential approach would be to push the multi-store logic down within each glance store driver's implementation. For example the store driver itself could contain logic to multiplex with multiple backends. While this approach would work, it would require each store driver's implementation to change and would result in suboptimal reuse of code. This spec proposes a multi-store approach which has little or no impact to each store driver; the can be used as-is in a multi-store implementation. By pushing the logic to support multiple stores of the same scheme up into the core of glance, we get maximal reuse and store driver implementations needn't be concerned with such logic. Data model impact ----------------- This spec does not propose any changes to the data model. Rather the approach herein can maintain all new stateful data either in memory or within the existing schema used by glance. From a stateful perspective this spec encapsulates the notion of a store with a unique store id. With the approach outlined in this spec we can keep the map of current stores and their respective store ids in memory as glance does today via the scheme_map [2]. As the store id is explicitly defined as the property group name used for the store in the glance-api.conf, glance core already has the id an the store instance itself need not be made aware of such a concept. Therefore, a listing of stores can be obtained by accessing or using helper functions to interface with the scheme_map (or similar). This spec also proposes the image location URLs have the store id added to the metadata for the URL. While this is a new 'default' behavior for multi-store, the URL metadata is already part of the glance schema; we're just proposing to add a well known attribute to it when uploading an image. That said, no data model impacts are foreseen at this time. REST API impact --------------- This spec proposes the following API changes: **New APIs** * List all stores known to the glance service. * Get details for a given store. **Modified APIs** * Download an image file. * Upload an image file. * Get image details. **Common Response Codes** * Create Success: `201 Created` * Modify Success: `200 OK` * Delete Success: `204 No Content` * Failure: `400 Bad Request` with details. * Forbidden: `403 Forbidden` * Not found: `404 Not found` if specific entity not found **API Version** All URLS will be under the v2 Glance API. If it is not explicitly specified assume /v2/<url> **[New API] List stores** List all stores known to the glance service:: GET /v2/stores This API takes no query parameters and when authorized returns a listing of all stores known to the glance service. The stores known to glance are those which have been configured in the glance-api.conf and have been loaded during glance startup. The response body payload is JSON and contains a JSON object per store. Each store JSON object contains the store's identifier (id), supported schemes, type and base locations. For example:: { "stores":[ { "id":"localfs", "type": "file", "schemes":[ "file", "filesystem" ], "locations":[ "file:///var/glance/images/", "filesystem:///var/glance/images/" ] }, { "id":"vsphere-east1", "type": "vmware", "schemes":[ "vsphere" ], "locations":[ "vsphere://10.11.12.13/dc1/" ] }, { "id":"vsphere-west1", "type": "vmware", "schemes":[ "vsphere" ], "locations":[ "vsphere://12.13.14.15/dc2/" ] } ] } As noted previously, if glance is not using multi-store each store is implicitly given an identifier of the store type (in which case 'id' and 'type' are the same). An example response to exemplify this behavior is shown below:: { "stores":[ { "id":"file", "type": "file", "schemes":[ "file", "filesystem" ], "locations":[ "file:///var/glance/images/", "filesystem:///var/glance/images/" ] }, { "id":"vmware", "type": "vmware", "schemes":[ "vsphere" ], "locations":[ "vsphere://10.11.12.13/dc1/" ] } ] } Response codes: * 200 -- Upon authorization and successful request. The response body contains the JSON payload with the known stores. * 403 -- When not authorized with the proper role to list glance stores. **[New API] Get store details** Get the details for a store given it's store ID:: GET /v2/stores/{store_id} This API takes no query parameters and when authorized returns the details of the specified 'store_id'. The store identifier was introduced in the 'Proposed changes' section of this spec. The response body payload is JSON and contains the JSON object which represents the store (see store JSON in the list stores API above). The store JSON object contains the store's identifier (id), supported schemes, type and base locations. For example:: { "id":"localfs", "type": "file", "schemes":[ "file", "filesystem" ], "locations":[ "file:///var/glance/images/", "filesystem:///var/glance/images/" ] } As noted previously, if glance is not using multi-store each store is implicitly given an identifier of the store type (in which case 'identifier' and 'type' are the same). An example response to exemplify this behavior is shown below:: { "id":"file", "type": "file", "schemes":[ "file", "filesystem" ], "locations":[ "file:///var/glance/images/", "filesystem:///var/glance/images/" ] } Response codes: * 200 -- Upon authorization and successful request. The response body contains the JSON payload with the known stores. * 403 -- When not authorized with the proper role to list glance stores. **[Modified API] Download image binary data** Get image binary data:: GET /v2/images/{image_id}/file This modifies the existing REST API to support a new header field which is optional and if present specifies the store id to get the image data from. For backwards compatibility, if the header is not specified the store specified as the default (e.g. default_store) is used to get the image data from. New header fields: * X-Image-Meta-Store -- If present contains the store id to get the image binary data from. New / changed response codes: * 400 -- If the X-Image-Meta-Store header is present, but specifies a store id for a store that doesn't exist by that id. Example curl usage:: curl -i -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "X-Image-Meta-Store: vsphere-west1" $image_url/v2/images/{image_id}/file **[Modified API] Upload image binary data** Get image binary data:: PUT /v2/images/{image_id}/file This modifies the existing REST API to support a new header field which is optional and if present specifies the store id to upload the image data to. For backwards compatibility, if the header is not specified the store specified as the default (e.g. default_store) is used to upload the image to. New header fields: * X-Image-Meta-Store -- If present contains the store id to upload the image binary data to. New / changed response codes: * 400 -- If the X-Image-Meta-Store header is present, but specifies a store id for a store that doesn't exist by that id. Example curl usage:: curl -i -X PUT -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "X-Image-Meta-Store: vsphere-west1" -H "Content-Type: application/octet-stream" -d @/home/glance/ubuntu-12.10.qcow2 $image_url/v2/images/{image_id}/file **[Modified API] Get image details** Get the details for a specified image:: GET /v2/images/{image_id} Although this spec does not impose any changes on the glance API layer, this call will now include image location URL metadata which shows the location's store id per image location URL. For example the image details JSON body will contain location metadata as shown below:: { "locations":[ { "url":"vsphere://10.90.80.22/folder/openstack_glance/c15e00ec-d3 ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b?dcPath=dc-e1&dsName=datastore2", "metadata":{ "store_id":"vsphere-east1" } }, { "url":"vsphere://9.10.30.11/folder/openstack_glance/c15e00ec-d3 ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b?dcPath=dc-w1&dsName=datastore1", "metadata":{ "store_id":"vsphere-west1" } } ] } NB: The store id is added when the URL is saved upon an image file upload. This section just outlines how that looks to API consumers. Security impact --------------- As this spec proposes a new REST API to list glance stores, we also propose to protect this API with a new policy check. Similar to other glance APIs, the API logic for the glance list stores REST API should check a new 'get_stores' policy prior to fulfilling a request. Proposed new policy:: get_stores This way deployers can determine which user roles can list glance stores in a coarse or fine grained approach. We also introduces a new API to get the details for a given store. As such a new policy should be added and checked during authorization (RBAC) to the get store details API. Proposed new policy:: get_store This way deployers can determine which user roles can get glance store details in a coarse or fine grained approach. This spec also introduces the notion of downloading / uploading image data to specific stores. While its foreseeable operators would want to control this on a per store basis, this spec proposes we continue to the existing glance policy checks in those paths. Notifications impact -------------------- No impacts -- uploading / downloading images to / from glance is an existing operation and this spec does not propose to change any existing notifications. Other end user impact --------------------- This proposal introduces a few other user impacts worth noting. **Glance client** Ideally the glance client (CLI + REST client) should be updated in accordance with this spec. Notably: * CLI / API support for listing glance stores. * CLI / API support for getting a store's details. * CLI / API support for specifying a store id on upload / download. **Configuration** Deployers will need to be aware of the configuration aspects for glance multi-store. From a conf point of view, configuring multi-store for glance will look very much (from a high level) like configuring cinder for multi-backend. The conf file specifics will need to be documented and likely devstack may need a few changes (TBD). Performance Impact ------------------ Nothing notable. Listing glance stores will effectively be an in-memory query and thus should be performant. Uploading and downloading images from target stores does not introduce and additional performance overhead with respect to the existing glance support. Other deployer impact --------------------- Once merged, glance multi-store is not enabled unless the deployer configures the enabled_stores property in glance-api.conf and thus is backwards compatible out-of-the-box. When multi-store is disabled, v2 API users can use the list stores API and will retrieve a list of the current stores configured (of course only 1 store per scheme). Developer impact ---------------- The approach proposed herein should have minimal developer impact. Glance store drivers should continue to function as-is without explicit knowledge of the multi-store semantics. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): nikhil-komawar arnaudleg Other reviewer(s): None Work Items ---------- Implementation tasks may consist of: * Conf support for multi-store. * Multi-store loading and indexing. * Implement base location method in each store driver. * List stores API. * Get store details API. * Location URL metadata store id on upload. * Image upload with store targeting. * Image download with store targeting. * Multi-store delete and other store access codepaths. * Work with ID team on changes / updates. * Work with devstack on any necessary changes. Dependencies ============ None identified to date. Testing ======= Ideally the glance tempest tests would be updated to include some coverage for the function contained herein. High level cover may include: * Variation 1: no multi-store support * Install OpenStack without multi-store enabled. * Ensure the REST API can be used to list the configured stores. * Ensure the REST API can be used to get details for each store configured. * Verify image upload works as expected (regression). * Test using both the store header to target a store as well as without. * Verify image download works as expected (regression). * Test using both the store header to target a store as well as without. * Variation 2: multi-store support * Install Openstack with multi-store enabled. For example 2 instances of the filesystem store driver. * Ensure the REST API can be used to list the configured stores. * Ensure the REST API can be used to get details for each store configured. * Verify image upload works as expected (regression). * Test using both the store header to target a store as well as without. When targeting a store, ensure the image bits get stored in the proper backend storage location. * Verify image download works as expected (regression). * Test using both the store header to target a store as well as without. When targeting a store, ensure the image bits get downloaded from the specified store. Documentation Impact ==================== As mentioned in the 'work items' section, we'll need to ensure the glance docs are update for: * The new list stores REST API. * New header field for image download. * New header field for image upload. * Store id in image location URL metadata. * Overall glance multi-store documentation to educate deployers on the feature and how it's used. References ========== [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder-multi-backend [2] https://github.com/openstack/glance_store/blob/master/glance_store/backend.py#L191 [3] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/location.py#L363

commit_message:
Spec for glance async image replication support

Although the current glance implementation supports multiple locations
per image, it currently does not support a means to replication image
bits onto a secondary glance store. As a result out-of-band-operations
may be required to back image bits on secondary storage.

This spec contains a proposal to introduce a new glance async task
for image replication between 2 glance stores. Leveraging this new
task will allow operators to copy image bits between store backends
using glance.

The replication support outlined in this spec paves the road for a
number of use cases related to image fault tolerance, image
locality and policy based image hosting.

Base on blueprint image-bits-replication

Change-Id: Ic21a897ca2b9dec747247068ea626604c5b39f72
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/71/150971/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Glance image bits replication ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/image-bits-replication The glance v2 API currently supports multiple locations per image and moreover we've proposed the introduction of glance multi-store support [1]. However even with glance multi-store support [1] the operator still doesn't have a clean story with respect to image replication between glance stores. Ideally an operator should be able to: * Use a glance async task to initiate an image replication (copy) from one configured store to another. This spec introduces a glance task [2] to automate the above case(s) in an async manner. Of course users leveraging this support get all the benefits of the glance async task framework such as the ability to poll tasks for status / completion (e.g. fire-and-monitor). NB: This BP doesn't cover replicating image bits cross-region; it targets image bit replication across stores within a single OpenStack deployment. For details on cross region replication, see the clone task BP [3]. NB: For this spec we assume replication = synchronization although that's a debatable definition. Problem description =================== In order to replicate image bits across different glance stores using multi-store support [1], the operator must either: * Copy the image bits out-of-band and update the image's locations with the new URL of the bits. * Use the multi-store [1] support to upload the image bits to the desired stores; an upload per store. Both of the above are less than optimal and can be automated using a glance async task [2]. By providing an image replication via an async task, we open the door to a number of use cases related to fault tolerance, image locality and policy based image hosting. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes the following high level features: * A new glance async task to initiate a replication of image bits from a source store to a destination store. Image replication is the act of copying image bits from one glance store to another. Obviously the logic to copy the image bits between store types or even store instances is not the same for all stores; there may be cases where the replication can be optimized based on the source and destination stores. For example, the most obvious / generic strategy is to stream all the image bits from the source store (source_store.get()) directly to destination store dest_store.add()). However this approach requires the image bits pipe through the glance API node which is an extra hop in the transfer. In comparison, consider a replication in which both the source and destination stores are VMware datastores accessible via the same vCenter. In this case the copy can be optimized using the vCenter APIs to directly copy from datastore-to-datastore (no glance API node hop in the transfer). As a result, this spec proposes the notion of a 'replication strategy' be introduced. A replication strategy is simply an interface / plugin mechanism which allows different implementations to handle the image copy logic. For example consider the following sample replication strategy driver (exact signature TBD when getting into code):: @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class AbstractImageReplicationStrategy(object): @abc.abstractmethod def replicate(self, image, source_store, dest_store): """ Replicate the said image from the source store to the dest store and returns a tuple containing information about the stored image. :param image: The image to replicate. :param source_store: Ref to the source store containing the image bits. :param dest_store: Ref to the dest store which should receive the image bits. :raises 'glance.replication.exceptions.UnhandledReplication' if the strategy does not support replicating the said image from source to dest. """ The replication strategy implementations can be registered using stevedore entry points in the setup.cfg. For example:: [entry_points] glance.replication.strategies = disabled = glance.replication.strategy.Disable stream = glance.replication.strategy.Stream # default vimcopy = glance.replication.strategy.vmware.VIMCopy As part of this spec, we propose 2 strategies be included with glance out-of-the-box as part of this effort: * stream - Copy image bits by piping the source stores get() to the destination store's add(). This logic is store independent, but of course comes at the price of streaming image bits through the glance API node. NB: ideally this implementation can stream image bits using memory only. However it may be necessary (TBD) to stream the bits to a local temp file and then upload to the destination store. * disabled - Effective no-op strategy indicating replication is disabled. We propose the strategy to be configurable using a 'replication_strategy' conf property. This property is a comma list of strategy names to use in order from left-to-right during a replication operation. A strategy can raise a well known exception to indicate it cannot fulfill the replication which signifies to glance to try the next strategy in the list, or if no more exist to fail the replication task. There are 2 cases with respect to replication configuration; one for multi-store [1] and once when not using multi-store: * Multi-store -- When using glance with multi-store support [1], the strategy is defined per store using a 'replication_strategy' property. Here the replication_strategy is a comma list of the strategies to use when replicating images to the store instance. If multiple strategies are given in the replication_strategy for a store, the strategies are tried in order from left-to-right (e.g. try vimcopy and if vimcopy cannot handle the replication fall back to stream). For example:: [glance-store] # list of enabled stores identified by their property group name # if not set multi-store is not used (backwards compat) enabled_stores = localfs,vsphere-east1,vsphere-west1 # the default store, if not set the 1st store is the default default_store = vsphere-east1 # etc.. # conf props for file system store instance [localfs] store_type = filesystem filesystem_store_datadir = /var/lib/images/data/ replication_strategy = stream # etc.. # conf props for vmware datastore store instance [vsphere-east1] store_type = vmware_datastore vmware_server_host = 9.10.78.11 replication_strategy = vimcopy,stream # etc.. # conf props for vmware datastore store instance [vsphere-west1] store_type = vmware_datastore vmware_server_host = 10.10.90.32 replication_strategy = vimcopy,stream # etc.. Note that if an operator does not want to support replicating images into a given store instance, they can specify the 'disabled' strategy. Also note that the strategy is defined on the destination store so that glance always gets the list of possible strategies by inspecting the destination. * Non multi-store -- When using glance without multi-store support [1], the 'replication_strategy' is used in the 'glance-store' property group to signify the strategies to use for the configured stores. Although this approach does not provide per store strategies, it does allow for a pipeline of replication strategies. For example:: [glance_store] # list of enabled stores identified by their property group name # if not set multi-store is not used (backwards compat) # --> multi-store is disabled #enabled_stores = # replication strategies to use on all configured stores replication_strategy = stream Within the replication async task framework, the core task code can then handle the replication task using the following pseudo code: * Determine the source and dest stores for the replication and obtain a reference to each. * Lookup the list of replication strategies for the dest store. * Obtain a reference to an instance for each strategy in the list. * Try each strategy instance in turn until one replicates the image or until one raises an exception other than UnhandledReplication (which is an indicator the current strategy cannot handle the replication and the next strategy should be tried). * If the replication is successful, store the location and store id for the image in the image's locations metadata to indicate the new backend for the image. * If no strategies can complete the replication or if one throws an exception (other than UnhandledReplication), fail the task accordingly. Note that if a strategy raises an unexpected exception, that exception fails the task and the task details should include information from the exception message to provide end user feedback. Forward notice: the REST API portion of this spec outline 3 different formats for addressing image locations: * Image location URL -- The direct image location which is constructed by the respective store's location implementation. This is the URL you see when you enable glance to show locations. For example:: file:///var/glance/images/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b * Store URL -- A URL of the form:: glance://{store_id}/{image_id} Where the 'store_id' is the ID of the target store and 'image_id' is the target image. This format allows glance to uniquely identify a backing store and the image of interest; enough information to properly lookup the image's direct URL from the target store. For example:: glance://vmware-east1/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b * Image ID -- The image ID only. This is a generic form which indicates glance should pick any store which backs the given image ID. Under the covers glance can simply pick the 1st tried store which backs the image. For example:: c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b Details on the REST API for the replication task are covered under the REST API impacts section of this spec. Alternatives ------------ **In-line replication during image upload** One possible alternative is develop the image replication logic directly into the image upload codepath so replication is done as part of upload (synchronously). While this is a feasible approach, image state and upload characteristics are highly dependant on this codepath and thus introduce complexity / performance. For reference please see the openstack-dev email list comments [4]. **Out-of-band replication** Another feasible approach entails developing a separate process / service which is responsible for the image replication out-of-band. Perhaps this external process is triggered based on glance notification and uses the glance API to add the secondary locations to the image once replicated. While this approach is most feasible now (as a stop gap), ideally the approach should allow operators / users to manage the image replication and status of such from a single pane of glance glass. Moreover, using a separate process for this solution introduces yet another service deployers need to install, configure and maintain. Given the glance async tasks are intended to operate on glance resources in an async fashion and eventually as part of glance request pipelines, they provide a firm building block to support the functionality proposed herein. Data model impact ----------------- No data model impacts foreseen at this point in time. The approach leverages the existing schema and model employed by glance v2. REST API impact --------------- This spec proposes the following API changes: **New APIs** * None **Modified APIs** * Initiate an async task to replicate an image from a source to destination store. **Common Response Codes** * Create Success: `201 Created` * Modify Success: `200 OK` * Delete Success: `204 No Content` * Failure: `400 Bad Request` with details. * Forbidden: `403 Forbidden` * Not found: `404 Not found` if specific entity not found **API Version** All URLS will be under the v2 Glance API. If it is not explicitly specified assume /v2/<url> **[Modified API] Replicate image** To initiate an async task to replicate an image between 2 stores:: POST /v2/tasks This is the standard v2 glance tasks API, however we propose to introduce a new async task type called 'replicate'. Based on the existing BP for the glance clone task [3], we propose following the same basic structure on the request body. For the replicate task, the request input must have the following attributes: * source -- The source to copy the image bits from. This input value comes in a few forms: * Location URL -- The direct image location URL to copy the bits from. * Image ID -- The image ID to copy bits from. In this case glance picks the 1st store which backs the image bits. * Store URL -- A URL of the form glance://{store_id}/{image_id} where the store_id is the store identifier and image_id is the image's ID. In this form glance will use the said store and image. * destination -- The ID of the destination store to copy the bits into. Approximations of the request body below. Using location URL (explicitly specify replication from source location):: { "type":"replicate", "input":{ "source":"file:///var/glance/images/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892 cdb6f5b", "destination":"vsphere-west1" } } Using image ID (let glance choose any store which backs the image for source):: { "type":"replicate", "input":{ "source":"c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b", "destination":"vsphere-west1" } } Using the store URL (explicitly specify replication from source store and image ID):: { "type":"replicate", "input":{ "source":"glance://localfs/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b", "destination":"vsphere-west1" } } Note: Perhaps we could consider supporting location URLs in the destination as well. However constructing a proper store location URL can be error prone and requires knowledge of the underlying store / storage. Therefore this spec focuses only on using a store ID as the destination; the store internals will handle placing the image bits on storage and creating a proper location URL. Response codes: * 201 -- As per standard glance async task response. * 403 -- When not authorized with the proper role to replicate. * 404 -- If the image, source or destination stores do not exist or are invalid. Security impact --------------- As this spec proposes a new REST API to replicate image bits, we also propose to protect this API with a new policy check. Similar to other glance APIs, the API logic for the replicate task REST API should check a new 'replicate_image' policy prior to fulfilling a request. Proposed new policy:: replicate_image This way deployers can determine which user roles can replicate image bits in a coarse or fine grained approach. Notifications impact -------------------- No new notifications proposed. Rather a completed replication should trigger the same notification as does v2 image upload to signify the image's successful replication to a new store location. Other end user impact --------------------- This proposal introduces a few other user impacts worth noting. **Glance client** Ideally the glance client (CLI + REST client) should be updated in accordance with this spec. Notably: * CLI / API support for initiating a replicate async task given an image and a source + dest. **Configuration** Deployers will need to be aware of the configuration aspects for glance replication should they choose to use it. From a conf point of view, configuring replication will require defining the replication_strategy per store (if using multi-store) or in the glance-store property group. Performance Impact ------------------ Depending on the replication strategy implementation, an async task to copy image bits between stores may range from minimal to substantial performance impact. If the strategy must stream the image bits through the glance API node resources on the node will be required for the duration of the replication. On the other hand, if the strategy uses backend APIs to perform the copy, little resources should be needed on the glance node as the heavy lifting is done on the backend itself. Regardless of which, the glance async tasks framework [2] is slated to employ parameters to control resource consumption of async tasks. Therefore from a performance point of view, operators should be able to parametrize the async task runtime behavior to achieve optimal performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- From a deployer perspective, this spec proposes we ship with the stream replication strategy as the default. In this case, by default, deployers can use image replication with the store agnostic streaming strategy. Moreover we propose the default role for the 'replicate_image' policy check be set to an admin role. This default setting ensures only 'admin' role users can leverage the functionality out-of-the-box. Should deployers choose to disable the replication task all together, they can set the replication strategy to disabled which will prevent the functionality all together, or simply unset the property. Developer impact ---------------- As discussed above, this spec introduces the notion of a replication strategy. As a result, developers will be able to implement and plug-in their own strategies as needed. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): nikhil-komawar arnaudleg Other reviewer(s): None Work Items ---------- Implementation tasks may consist of: * Core task logic to support the loading and lookup of replication strategies. * Task API logic which supports the workflow to implement the task itself. * Implementation of the disabled strategy. * Implementation of the stream strategy. * Work with ID team on changes / updates. * Work with devstack on any necessary changes. Dependencies ============ [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/multi-store Testing ======= Ideally the glance tempest tests are updated to include some coverage for the functionality proposed herein. Some high level areas for coverage: * Variation 1: no multi-store replication * Install OpenStack without multi-store support and 2 different store drivers (ex: filesystem and cinder). * Create an image and upload it's bits to glance. * Use the replication async task to replicate the image bits to the other configured store. * Verify upon task completion that the bits are backed on the other store and that the image's locations metadata is updated to reflect the additional location. * Variation 2: multi-store replication * Install OpenStack with multi-store enabled and 2 stores of the same type (ex: 2 filesystem stores). * Create an image and upload it's bits to glance. * Use the replication async task to replicate the image bits to the other store of the same type. * Verify upon task completion that the bits are backed on the other store and that the image's locations metadata is updated to reflect the additional location. * Variation 3: multi-store replication to different store types * Install OpenStack with multi-store enabled and 2 stores of the same type (ex: 2 filesystem stores) in addition to another store of a different type (e.g. cinder). * Create an image and upload it's bits to glance targeting one of the stores of the same scheme (ex: filesystem). * Use the replication async task to replicate the image bits to the other store of the different type. * Verify upon task completion that the bits are backed on the other store and that the image's locations metadata is updated to reflect the additional location. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation changes will be required in the following areas: * Glance configuration; how to configure replication strategies. * A listing of the out-of-the-box strategies and their behavior. * Dev docs on how to implement your own strategy. References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/multi-store [2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Glance-tasks-api [3] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Glance-tasks-clone [4] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-January/054399.html

commit_message:
Spec for glance async image deletion support

Although the current glance implementation supports multiple locations
per image, it currently does not support a means to delete image bits
from specified backend stores. As a result out-of-band-operations
may be required to delete image bits on secondary storage.

This spec contains a proposal to introduce a new glance async task
to delete an image's backing bits from a specified location. The
spec also includes a means to delete all locations from a given
image in an async task manner. Leveraging this new task will allow
operators to more easily manage image bits on backend locations
using glance.

The deletion support outlined in this spec compliments the
blueprint multi-store and also the blueprint async-image-deletion
to provide a more holistic way to manage image storage using
glance.

Based on blueprint async-image-deletion

Change-Id: I04b6159e92880d415035aa7abedf2481cbd57132
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/86/150986/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Glance async image deletion task ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/image-bits-replication The glance v2 API currently supports multiple locations per image and moreover we've proposed the introduction of glance multi-store support [1] as well as a blueprint to support async image replication between glance stores [4]. However even with these proposed features the operator still doesn't have a clean story with respect to image deletion from a specific store location(s). Ideally an operator should be able to: * Use a glance async task to initiate the deletion of an image from a specific store it's backed on. This spec introduces a glance async task [2] to automate the above case(s) in an async manner. Of course users leveraging this support get all the benefits of the glance async tasks such as the ability to poll tasks for status / completion (e.g. fire-and-monitor). Problem description =================== Glance image bits may be backed on multiple locations (either via out-of-band replication, using multi-store [1] or image replication [4]). However, today operators have the following means to delete image bits: * Use glance v2 delete image API -- this will delete the image bits from ALL locations. * out-of-band -- delete the image bits manually out-of-band and then use the glance API to update the image's locations to delete the location registered in the image's metadata. Ideally glance should support a means to delete an image's bits from a specified location. Such support would enhance the user experience and reduce error prone out-of-band operations with respect to image storage management. Moreover async image location deletion coupled with multi-store [1] and async image replication [4] will provide a more complete story around image storage management and policies opening the door for a number of use cases. This spec proposes a glance async task [2] to initiate a store targeted deletion (deletion from a specific location) of a given image's bits. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes the following high level features: * A new glance async task to initiate the deletion of a given location, or all locations, from a specified image. Using the delete async task, users will be able to fire-and-monitor image deletion tasks to delete image bits from specific locations, or to remove image bits from all known locations for a given image. The logic necessary to implement the delete task is fairly straight forward and can be built atop the constructs outlined in [1] and [4]. From a high level perspective, the following flow can be implemented: * Look-up the respective store based on the location specified in the delete task request (see below for applicable location formats). * Use the store's delete() method to delete the image bits from the specified location. Note: in the case of deleting all locations, delete() is called for each store associated with the specified image. * IF the store's delete() method is successful, remove the location URL from the image's locations metadata; the task is successful. * IF the store's delete() method is not successful, collect relevant details about the failure to associate with the task status and fail the task. As discussed in the REST API section of this document, there are 3 forms of addressing the image location(s) to delete: * Image location URL -- The direct image location which is constructed by the respective store's location implementation. This is the URL you see when you enable glance to show locations. For example:: file:///var/glance/images/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b * Store URL -- A URL of the form:: glance://{store_id}/{image_id} Where the 'store_id' is the ID of the target store and 'image_id' is the target image. This format allows glance to uniquely identify a backing store and the image of interest; enough information to properly lookup the image's direct URL from the target store. For example:: glance://vmware-east1/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b * Image ID -- The image ID only. This is a generic form which indicates glance should pick any store which backs the given image ID. Under the covers glance can simply pick the 1st tried store which backs the image. For example:: c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b Under the covers, the delete task effectively calls the respective store's delete() method. However, the logic must account for multi-store support [1] as well as deletion of all image locations for a specified image. To handle store lookup in these cases, the following logic can be used: * IF the location is addressed as an direct image location URL, search the stores indexed by the location scheme and compare the store's base location (see [1]) with the location URL. If the location URL starts with the base location the target store has been found and can be used for the delete. Note: an alternative approach here might be to add a method to the glance store driver interface to check if the store instance can access a given image location. For example consider the following method which could be added to the store interface:: def has_location(self, location): """ Returns True if the store can access the given location and False otherwise. """ * IF the location is addressed as a store location (e.g. glance://{store_id}/{image_id}), lookup the store using scheme_map[scheme][store_id]. If the store exists it's the target store and can be used for the delete operation. * IF the location is an image ID, obtain the image's location URLs and follow the approach outlined above for the image location URL for each location of the image. For each target store, use it's delete() to remove the image bits. Note: ideally these delete operations can be implemented in a parallel fashion such that multiple deletes don't need to occur one-after-another in parallel. Note: if any of the deletes fail the task is considered failed, even though some locations may have been removed. Alternatives ------------ **RESTy deletion of image locations** Another possible approach for supporting deletion of individual image locations is to expose locations as a REST (sub)resource of images. For example imagine we had the following REST resources for glance images:: /v2/images/{image_id}/locations/ /v2/images/{image_id}/locations/{store_id} In the above sample URLs, a GET on /v2/images/{image_id}/locations/ would return a list of store_ids; one store_id per location of the image bits (e.g. the stores which back the image bits for the image's current locations). A user could then initiate a location deletion using:: DELETE /v2/images/{image_id}/locations/{store_id} Where the store_id is the location store_id the user wants to remove the bits from. While this approach is appealing from a RESTful perspective, it's slightly obtuse in that: * We would typically think of locations as the location URL, not the store_id. However the actual location URL is not a proper URI segment and hence can't be used as the {store_id} above. * From a REST point of view, users would likely expect additional operations on the locations sub resource of an image. For example the ability to POST new locations, delete them etc.. While this may be appealing and desirable longer term (e.g. v3) implementing these constructs in v2 would cause substantial churn in the API. * In this model, we'd still be doing deletion in a synchronous fashion. Deletion operations fall more naturally and usefully into async tasks which support fire-and-monitor. **v2 image delete using targeted locations** Another possibility for this functionality is to enhance the existing v2 image delete REST API to support a means of specifying an image location to delete. For example, imagine the v2 image delete REST API supported a header field who's value specified a image location to delete. Using this approach users would still use the existing v2 image delete API, but could specify a location to delete in a header field. For example:: curl -i -X DELETE -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "X-Image-Meta-Store: file:///var/glance/images/{image_id}" $image_url/v2/images/{image_id} While this approach is feasible, it has the following downfalls: * The v2 image delete REST API would become less RESTy. Based on the verb / URL one would expect the image in its entirety to be deleted, but in fact when using the special header that would not be the case. * The operation would still happen in a synchronous fashion and would not support the fire-and-monitor approach employed by glance tasks. **CLI tool** Targeted image deletion could also be achieved by developing a separate CLI / client capable of deleting image bits on a per location basis (similar to the glance-replicator tool). This approach is doable, however consider: * There would be no REST API for the targeted deletion. REST APIs are the primary means for integration these days and thus this approach would likely not reach a bulk of our audience. * Given the tool would need to interface with glance stores, it would likely depend on the glance projects (as dependencies) and moreover would likely require extensive configuration when not run on the glance API node to ensure the stores used by the tool are properly configured. Data model impact ----------------- No data model impacts foreseen at this point in time. The approach leverages the existing schema and model employed by glance v2. REST API impact --------------- This spec proposes the following API changes: **New APIs** * None **Modified APIs** * Initiate an async task to delete an image from a specific store location. **Common Response Codes** * Create Success: `201 Created` * Modify Success: `200 OK` * Delete Success: `204 No Content` * Failure: `400 Bad Request` with details. * Forbidden: `403 Forbidden` * Not found: `404 Not found` if specific entity not found **API Version** All URLS will be under the v2 Glance API. If it is not explicitly specified assume /v2/<url> **[Modified API] Delete image location** To initiate an async task to delete an image from a given location:: POST /v2/tasks This is the standard v2 glance tasks API. However we propose to introduce a new async task type called 'delete'. Based on the existing BP for the glance clone task [3], we propose to follow the same basic structure on the request body. For the delete task, the request input must have the following attributes: * source -- The location of image bits to delete. This input value comes in a few forms: * Image location URL -- The full image location URL to delete the bits from. * Image ID -- The image ID to delete bits from. In this case glance deletes the image bits from all locations. This is effectively the async version of v2 image delete, but image metadata remains intact. * Store URL -- A URL of the form glance://{store_id}/{image_id} where the store_id is the store identifier and image_id is the image's ID. In this form glance will use the said store and image. For example the request body looks approximately like this:: Using location URL (delete the source location):: { "type":"delete", "input":{ "source":"file:///var/glance/images/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b" } } Using image ID (deletes all locations, but not image metadata):: { "type":"delete", "input":{ "source":"c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b" } } Using the store URL (deletes image's location for given store):: { "type":"delete", "input":{ "source":"glance://localfs/c15e00ec-d3ff-480d-9b51-c7892cdb6f5b", } } Response codes: * 201 -- As per standard glance async task response. * 403 -- When not authorized with the proper role to delete. * 404 -- If the image, source or destination stores do not exist or are invalid. Security impact --------------- This spec introduces a new glance async task which deletes image bits based on a location, or deletes all locations (e.g. v2 image delete) and as a result should only be executed under the appropriate policy check. Glance already defines the following policy check which should also be checked in the async delete task prior to initiating the delete operation:: delete_image_location This way deployers can determine which user roles can delete image bits in a coarse or fine grained approach. Notifications impact -------------------- Given this spec proposes the ability to delete image locations, it makes sense to introduce a new notification indicating the location delete operation completed. That said we propose the following notification be sent upon successful image bit deletion from a location:: location.delete This notification would be sent for each location deleted so that consumers have a current / full picture of the image state. The payload for this notification should include the image's locations so that consumers have immediate visibility into the image's locations. However we propose that the locations in the payload be gated by the existing glance configuration property:: show_multiple_locations If 'show_multiple_locations' is False, the notification payload will not contain locations metadata. If True, the locations metadata will be included in the payload. Other end user impact --------------------- This proposal introduces a few other user impacts worth noting. **Glance client** Ideally the glance client (CLI + REST client) should be updated in accordance with this spec. Notably: * CLI / API support for initiating a delete async task given an image ID, store_id + image ID or a URL. **Configuration** Deployers will need to be aware of the configuration and notification aspects of this implementation. For example: * A new notification is emitted and the payload locations inclusion can be turned on / off with the 'show_multiple_locations' property. * RBAC can be controlled via the 'delete_image_location' policy check. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance of image / location deletion is largely dependant on the store driver used. Store drivers which interface with a remote service / device for image bit storage will impact the glance API node's resources very little as the backend is doing the heavy lifting. On the other hand if the store driver stores image bits locally; image deletion can be taxing to the glance API node. In either case, the glance API already supports deleting images and thus we are not expecting this implementation to be an less performant than that implementation. If anything perhaps deleting all image locations will be more performant since we suggested the deletes be done in parallel. Regardless of which, the glance async tasks framework [2] is slated to employ parameters to control resource consumption of async tasks. Therefore from a performance point of view, operators should be able to parametrize the async task runtime behavior to achieve optimal performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- Today the glance policy.json file ships with 'delete_image_location' set to empty and as a result by default users can delete image locations. That said an ideal out-of-the-box policy with the function introduced in this spec would be to ship glance with the 'delete_image_location' set to the admin role. For example:: "delete_image_location": "role:admin", This would by default require an admin role to delete image bits from backend locations. However, we should follow-up / discuss to understand if this policy change would impact our existing deployers. With respect to image deletion notifications, the current shipped glance-api.conf does not have 'show_multiple_locations' enabled. As a result out-of-the-box image location deletion notifications will not include location metadata. This is ideal and we should provide clear documentation to our deployers on how to enabled location metadata by setting 'show_multiple_locations' to True. e.g.:: # If True, then locations metadata is shown in the image details API # and is also included in location.delete notifications show_multiple_locations = True Developer impact ---------------- If we decide the 'has_location' method is appropriate for the store driver interface (see the 'Proposed change' section), the store driver developers would need to ensure this new method was implemented correctly. Depending on the store driver, such implementation may require a call to the backend to ensure connectivity for the given location, or in other cases can be fulfilled in memory. Other than that, no notable developer impact expect to date. The delete glance task should be fairly isolated to the task implementation itself (given the dependencies are in place). Store driver developers need only be concerned with implementing delete() correctly in their store driver implementation. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): nikhil-komawar arnaudleg Other reviewer(s): None Work Items ---------- Potential breakdown of tasks: * Task API logic which supports the workflow to implement the task itself. * Support for policy (RBAC) check. * Notification support for the 'location.delete' message. * Tempest tests. * Work with ID team on changes / updates. * Work with devstack on any necessary changes. Dependencies ============ [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/multi-store [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/image-bits-replication Note that dependency [2] above is not a hard dependency. However there very well be some shared / common code between the two. Testing ======= Ideally glance tempest tests would be enhanced to include a few variations of the image delete async task. The below recommendations outline a potential approach: * Variation 1: No multi-store delete of location * Configure glance with 2 different store drivers, not using multi-store support [1]. For example the file store and the cinder store. * Create an image and upload the image bits to both stores for the image. See [1] for details on uploading to a store. * Test an async delete of a single location; ensure only deleted from specified location and the image's locations metadata is updated. * Variation 2: No multi-store delete of image * Same as variation 1, however when submitting the async delete task specify the image ID and ensure both image locations are removed (and backing image bits). * Variation 3: Multi-store delete of location * Configure 2 stores of the same type using [1]. For example 2 instances of the filesystem store (each pointing to separate FS dir for images). * Create an image and upload the image bits to both stores for the image. See [1] for details on uploading to a store. * Test an async delete of a single location; ensure only deleted from specified location and the image's locations metadata is updated. * Variation 4: Multi-store delete of image * Same as variation 3, however when submitting the async delete task specify the image ID and ensure both image locations are removed (and backing image bits). Documentation Impact ==================== OpenStack glance docs will need updating in the following areas: * Details of the REST API for the delete async task including the request body input. * Information on the policy check for the delete async task. * Overview of location.delete notification and how location metadata can be included / excluded. * Perhaps, updates to the glance CLI if the glanceclient is also updated to support the task. References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/multi-store [2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Glance-tasks-api [3] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Glance-tasks-clone [4] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/image-bits-replication [5] https://github.com/openstack/glance_store/blob/master/glance_store/backend.py#L191

subject: Fix NTP verify appearing before install
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-05 04:21:33.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/source/environment-ntp-verify.rst', 'doc/install-guide/source/environment-ntp.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/ec25954df1ee498bf8990f935b0f835bc4d92355', 'message': "Fix NTP verify appearing before install

Due to the way the toctree was working on this page, the
steps to verify the NTP installation:
a) appeared prominently on the initial page, leading to
people wanting to try them before installing the service
b) were not available in a logical order when using the

This patch adds a new file for the verify steps to fix a)

commit_message:
Fix NTP verify appearing before install

Due to the way the toctree was working on this page, the
steps to verify the NTP installation:
a) appeared prominently on the initial page, leading to
people wanting to try them before installing the service
b) were not available in a logical order when using the
previous/next buttons

This patch adds a new file for the verify steps to fix a)
and b) and includes it from the toctree. It's a solution,
but may not be the best solution.

Change-Id: I14b977147e70bf29ea42e40bb337c89426e6b8d5
Closes-Bug: 1501704
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/68/230868/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: environment-ntp-verify.rst
deleted_lines: Verify operation ---------------- We recommend that you verify NTP synchronization before proceeding further. Some nodes, particularly those that reference the controller node, can take several minutes to synchronize. #. Run this command on the *controller* node: .. code-block:: console # chronyc sources 210 Number of sources = 2 MS Name/IP address Stratum Poll Reach LastRx Last sample =============================================================================== ^- 192.0.2.11 2 7 12 137 -2814us[-3000us] +/- 43ms ^* 192.0.2.12 2 6 177 46 +17us[ -23us] +/- 68ms Contents in the *Name/IP address* column should indicate the hostname or IP address of one or more NTP servers. Contents in the *S* column should indicate *\** for the server to which the NTP service is currently synchronized. #. Run the same command on *all other* nodes: .. code-block:: console # chronyc sources 210 Number of sources = 1 MS Name/IP address Stratum Poll Reach LastRx Last sample =============================================================================== ^* controller 3 9 377 421 +15us[ -87us] +/- 15ms Contents in the *remote* column should indicate the hostname of the controller node.

commit_message:
Spacing Fix for cloud archive repo add

The instructions to add the cloud archive repo had additional
spacing in them, resulting in this error:

root@controller:~# echo "deb http://ubuntu-cloud.archive.canonical.com/ubuntu" \
>   "trusty-updates/liberty main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ \
>   cloudarchive-liberty.list
-su: /etc/apt/sources.list.d/: Is a directory

This patch fixes the extraneous spacing.

Change-Id: Id11ab288caaa774bea2dd6034ebec2f196f559bb
Implements: blueprint installguide-liberty

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Fix incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected) as below.
  assertEqual(observed, expected) => assertEqual(expected, observed)

Target of this patch:
  manila/tests/api/*

Note:
I also fix following asserts aruond above fixed parts.
  assertEqual(xx, True), assertEqual(True, xx) => assertTrue(xx)

As for assertFalse,
I do not convert assertEqual(xx, False) to assertFalse(xx)
because assertFalse(None) does not raise exception.

Change-Id: I8131946efef654235b5e32344b3f5e42ab3d3ced
Partial-Bug: #1259292
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/13/229713/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertEqual(six.b("Test result"), result.body) self.assertEqual("Router result", result.body)
deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(result.body, six.b("Test result")) self.assertEqual(result.body, "Router result")

subject: Make __all__ immutable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-01 17:17:03.000000000', 'files': ['keystonemiddleware/opts.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/commit/7e362fd3495bfeb59177113fd9ae1abca568362e', 'message': "Make __all__ immutable

Using a mutable type implies that it's acceptable for the set of
publicly-accessible attributes to be mutated at runtime, which defeats
their intended purpose of documenting the public interface. Tuples are
immutable.

Change-Id: Ib3ab93224ba240040b08ece481ef5ba620c3f658
"}]
commit_message:
Make __all__ immutable

Using a mutable type implies that it's acceptable for the set of
publicly-accessible attributes to be mutated at runtime, which defeats
their intended purpose of documenting the public interface. Tuples are
immutable.

Change-Id: Ib3ab93224ba240040b08ece481ef5ba620c3f658
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/25/230025/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

release keystonemiddleware 2.3.1

commit_message:
Fixes zuul failure

template-validate is now updated to validate the template
by using stack create validation path, which causes some of
the existing templates in this repository to fail.
so this patch is added to mark them as invalid and skip them
as part of template validation.

It was failing becuase of circular reference among the resources
in these invalid templates.

depends-on: I15891196be94d1e100869edeba0a7ef557edb36a
Change-Id: I6a003f35495bb43e0ca2a824eb9e503c4059c37a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/44/226244/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[sitemap] increase the DOWNLOAD_WARNSIZE

The default value for the DOWNLOAD_WARNSIZE setting is 33554432 (32MB).
This patch will double the value. This solves the following warning:

---snip---
WARNING: Received (37889579) bytes larger than download warn size
(33554432).
---snap---

Change-Id: I5be4bcefa6fe2eb474901bb958669978dd6e1fef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/18/230318/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DOWNLOAD_WARNSIZE = 67108864

Add ops:sdk-support tag

A new tag which provides general information to users regarding the number of
software development kits (SDKs) which support a particular service project.

Change-Id: I48d2f459b8c8d7d7f58b738a2034570e88815507
